awd_titl_txt: Participation Support for Students to Attend the 22nd American Conference on Crystal Growth and Epitaxy, Virtual, August 2-4, 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides participant support for attendees of the 22nd American Conference on Crystal Growth and Epitaxy to be held virtually from August 2-4, 2021. The symposium focuses on new research and development activities in bulk crystal and epitaxial thin film growth. The students and faculty present through oral and poster sessions their latest research results to the crystal growth and epitaxy, advanced manufacturing and broader engineering communities. Priority is given to student and young faculty participants who are women or who come from underrepresented minority groups. This approach promotes diverse participation at the conference, in the short term, and in STEM fields, in the long term. This award benefits the nation through the education of a skilled and diverse manufacturing workforce, which is better prepared to provide transformative solutions the challenges in their chosen fields. The conference plays an important role in supporting and sustaining the important field of crystal growth and epitaxy, which is an important component of semiconductor research. This conference is timely because of renewed interest in the revitalization of semiconductor manufacturing in the U.S.

This participant support is expected to benefit the students' professional, scientific and technical development. Attendance at the conference gives the students and faculty a broader view of crystal growth and thin film epitaxy, its fundamentals, advanced manufacturing, advanced characterization, and applications. Symposium topics include fundamentals of materials synthesis, crystal structure analysis, deposition and crystal growth techniques and processes, high throughput manufacturing, process modeling, monitoring and control, and specialized topics, such as 2D nanomaterials.  Attendees will learn about state-of-the-art research in their technical areas via access to several technical and professional development talks by leading domestic and international speakers. Students and young faculty enhance their communication skills through oral and poster presentations and in-depth discussions of their work with peers in their technical areas. This interactive experience significantly broadens student education, increases their enthusiasm for their research topic, acquaints them with expectations for scientific careers, and exposes them to new approaches for innovative research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project provided funds for graduate students and early career researchers participants to attend the 22nd American Conference on Crystal Growth and Epitaxy (ACCGE-22) which was held virtually from August 2-4, 2021.  Continuing a tradition, ACCGE-22 was held in conjunction with the 20th Biennial Workshop on Organometallic Vapor Phase Epitaxy (OMVPE-20). The virtual event in 2021 was organized and hosted by the American Association for Crystal Growth (AACG).

The scientific program of ACCGE-22/OMVPE-20 consisted of 25 topical symposia covering both theoretical and experimental aspects of growth and characterization of semiconducting, oxide, metallic, organic and biological crystals. Two plenary lectures were presented by Prof. Shuji Nakamura (UC-Santa Barbara) and Prof. Valeria Molinero (Univ. Utah). The technical symposia included approximately 120 invited presentations from researchers representing a broad swath of the field including presentations from industrial researchers focused on process scale-up and manufacturing.

The virtual ACCGE-22/OMVPE-20 conference was very successful with 404 participants which significantly exceeded typical in-person attendance numbers of 275-350 of prior meetings. This included 109 student attendees who paid a reduced registration fee.

There were more than 120 invited speakers and 160 contributed talks, and ~30 posters.  Attendance at the virtual sessions was quite good with 200-300 attendees for the plenary talks. The attendance numbers were especially notable because many of the speakers were international, with up to a 13-hour time difference. 

Intellectual Merit

Crystal growth has historically occupied an awkward position among the scientific and engineering disciplines. In the condensed matter physics and materials discovery communities, crystal growth and epitaxy are often considered as a means to an end ? the production of samples for property measurements.  However, the science and practice of crystal growth has played a central role in creating our current information and digital age as evidenced by the breakthroughs enabled by bulk growth of single crystal silicon, strained silicon-germanium epitaxy and III-nitride heteroepitaxy, to name a few. 

 The ACCGE-22/OMVPE-20 played an important role in supporting and sustaining the field of crystal growth in the U.S. Symposium topics included concepts related to the fundamentals of materials synthesis (thermodynamics, transport phenomena, kinetics), crystal structure (defects, characterization methods), techniques (solution growth, epitaxy, vapor phase deposition, bulk growth), manufacturing (high throughput processing, in situ monitoring, process modeling) and specialized topics (2D materials, textured ceramics, ferroelectrics, microfluidic processing). 

Broader Impact

ACCGE-22/OMVPE-20 provided professional development opportunities for graduate students and early career researchers to present the results of their research and interact with a larger network of professionals in the crystal growth field. Proceedings from the conference were published in the Journal of Crystal Growth. A photo contest was held to allow participants to share compelling scientific and artistic images arising from their research.  Additional social activities during coffee breaks promoted engagement of participants within the virtual platform.

The ACCGE conference has historically had substantial participation from crystal growth practitioners in industry both as attendees and organizers.  Consequently, several technical sessions were devoted to issues relevant to manufacturing and commercialization of bulk crystals and epitaxial thin films including topics such as process modeling and scale-up, in situ monitoring and characterization and equipment design for high throughput processing. The substantial industry involvement in the meeting provided graduate student attendees with exposure to industry-relevant problems in manufacturing and opportunities to network and learn about career opportunities.

Modified by: Joan Redwing
